content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?> <metadata xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://data.nodc.noaa.gov/coris/data/CoRIS/fgdc_schema_coris/fgdc-std-001-1998.xsd">  <idinfo>   <citation>    <citeinfo>     <origin>James C. Hendee</origin>     <pubdate>20140930</pubdate>     <title>ICON - Salt River Bay 2013 Meteorological and Oceanographic Observations (NODC Accession 0124001)</title>     <onlink>http://data.nodc.noaa.gov/accession/0124001</onlink>    </citeinfo>   </citation>   <descript>    <abstract>The Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory (AOML) of OAR is conducting research on the influence of meteorological and oceanographic factors upon coral bleaching, and other biogeochemical processes occurring on coral reefs.  Instrument arrays to measure the various environmental influences are being deployed at key coral reef areas to gain long-term temporally intensive data coverage, to provide near real-time information products, and to surface-truth NOAA satellite sea surface temperature (SST) products used for coral bleaching predictions ("HotSpot" products).  OAR has developed expert system software plus the instrument array (together called an Integrated Coral Observing Network, or ICON, station) to screen data in near real-time to test for appropriate data ranges for each of the instruments, and to issue "alerts" as to conditions thought to be conducive to coral bleaching, and other modeled events.  At each ICON station, local collaborators also provide feedback on the presence and progress of coral bleaching and thus validate coral bleaching predictions made by satellite HotSpots and ICON information products.</abstract>    <purpose>The impetus for such a framework was the perceived marked regional decline in coral reefs and the critical need to provide data and options for resource management.</purpose>    <supplinf>Temperature is in degrees Celsius; barometric pressure is in millibars; wind speed is in knots; wind direction is in degrees of compass; ultraviolet radiation is in units of uW cm-2 nm-1; photosynthetically active radiation is in units of uEinsteins m-2 s-1; conductivity is in milliSiemens cm-1; sea pressure is in decibars; instrument depth is in meters; salinity is in practical salinity units; relative humidity is in percentages; rain amount is in millimeters; rain duration is in seconds; rain intensity is in millimeters per hour; -9 in the data set indicates that the parameter is unavailable.  Detailed parameters description can be found in the "Definition of Data Terms" worksheet in this file: http://data.nodc.noaa.gov/coris/data/NOAA/oar/ICONstations/2013/icon-srvi2-2013-meta.xlsx</supplinf>   </descript>   <timeperd>    <timeinfo>     <rngdates>      <begdate>20130101</begdate>      <enddate>20131231</enddate>     </rngdates>    </timeinfo>    <current>ground condition</current>   </timeperd>   <status>    <progress>In work</progress>    <update>Unknown</update>   </status> Hendee</cntper>      <cntorg>Ocean Chemistry and Ecosystems Division, Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration</cntorg>     </cntperp>     <cntaddr>      <addrtype>mailing and physical address</addrtype>      <address>4301 Rickenbacker Causeway</address>      <city>Miami</city>      <state>Florida</state>      <postal>33149-1026</postal>      <country>USA</country>     </cntaddr>     <cntvoice>305-361-4396</cntvoice>    </cntinfo>   </ptcontac>  </idinfo>  <dataqual>   <attracc>    <attraccr>Data has been reviewed and edited in attempt to remove unreliable values.</attraccr>   </attracc>   <logic>none</logic>   <complete>Time; Air Temperature (2 sensors); Minimum and Average Barometric Pressure (2 sensors); Maximum and Average Wind Speeds and Directions (2 sensors); Photosynthetically Active Radiation (PAR) and Ultraviolet Radiation B (305, 330 and 380 nm) both above the water's surface and underwater, shallow and deep (3 sensors in all); Conductivity, Sea Temperature, Sea Pressure, Instrument Depth and Salinity (2 sensors, shallow and deep); Relative Humidity; Dew Point (calculated); Rain Amount, Duration and Intensity are the available parameters.  Known data issues include: 1) Deep PAR/UV sensor was largely offline through August 1st.    2) Shallow PAR/UV sensor, though its data are not redacted, shows signs of biofouling, most obviously in November and December.    3) One incomplete record (August 1st at 17:00) is redacted after station shutdown/restart.    4) Shallow CTD data are unreliable beginning August 1st.    5) Deep CTD pressures and depths are unreliable beginning August 1st.    6) Station underwent cleaning/maintenance operations on March 1st, June 13th, and December 3rd.    7) Station was offline July 30th through August 1st while all instruments (except the Surface PAR/UV sensor) were replaced. 8) Except where noted for the Surface PAR/UV sensor, most instruments were installed on May 26th, 2011, and then replaced on August 1st, 2013.</complete>   <lineage>    <procstep>     <procdesc>Data have been manually screened and erroneous values due to instrument malfunction have been noted and/or removed.</procdesc>     <procdate>20140930</procdate>    </procstep>   </lineage>  </dataqual>    <distinfo>   <distrib>    <cntinfo>     <cntperp>      <cntper>James C.
